title: 111_s3238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The tragic deaths on September 11, 2001 have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the attacks in New York City and Washington, DC are recognized. The heroic actions of individuals on September 11, 2001, including passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93, officers, emergency workers, and government employees, prevented further casualties and ensured the safety of many. The heroic actions on September 11, 2001, prevented further casualties and ensured safety, warranting recognition with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 to receive Congressional Medals. The President is authorized to award the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and memorials in recognition of their sacrifices on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs for the presentations. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Pentagon, and on Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175. The Secretary of the Treasury will create medals to honor those who died in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Pentagon, and on Flight 11, United Airlines Flight 175, Flight 93, and American Airlines Flight 77. Consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties will precede the final design decision. The Secretary of the Treasury will create silver and gold medals to honor individuals who died in the 9/11 attacks, including passengers and crew of American Airlines Flight 77. Consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties will precede the final design decision. Eligibility for the medal includes individuals who died on or after September 11, 2001, as a direct result of the acts of terrorism within the United States on that date. Any individual who died on or after September 11, 2001, as a direct result of the acts of terrorism within the United States on that date, shall be eligible for a medal authorized by the Secretary in consultation with relevant officials. The Secretary will create duplicate bronze medals for recipients of the medals authorized in section 3, to be displayed in precinct houses, firehouses, and other duty stations where individuals who responded to the 9/11 attacks were assigned. These individuals include officers, emergency workers, and government employees who perished as a direct result of the terrorist acts. Establishment of lists of recipients. The Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal under the Act, including victims from September 11, 2001. Consultation with specific offices will be done for making determinations. The Secretary will consult specific offices to establish lists of eligible recipients for medals under the Act, including victims from September 11, 2001. The determinations made are final and not subject to judicial review. If any individual becomes eligible for a medal or duplicate medal, the Secretary will promptly add them to the list. The inclusion or exclusion of individuals on lists for medals under the Act is not subject to judicial review. If someone becomes eligible for a medal, the Secretary will promptly add their name to the appropriate list. SEC. 6. The Secretary can sell duplicate bronze medals to cover costs. SEC. 7. Medals under this Act are national medals.
